<!-- Thank you for using Flutter!

     If you are looking for support, please check out our documentation
     or consider asking a question on Stack Overflow:
      * https://flutter.dev/
      * https://api.flutter.dev/
      * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/flutter?sort=frequent

     If you have found a bug or if our documentation doesn't have an answer
     to what you're looking for, then fill out the template below. Please read
     our guide to filing a bug first: https://flutter.dev/docs/resources/bug-reports
-->

## Steps to Reproduce

<!-- Please include full steps to reproduce so that we can reproduce the problem. -->

1. Create a new project and add **google_maps_flutter** to it
2. Implement the GoogleMap widget into a new page.
3. Create a new page that will have a button which on click will navigate you to the page with the GoogleMapWidget
4. Click back and you will see what I mean

**Expected results:** <!-- what did you want to see? -->
Google maps to be pushed back and fade out as other UI elements.




**Actual results:** <!-- what did you see? -->
Google maps is pushed back but just disappears

<details>
<summary>Code sample</summary>

<!--
      Please create a minimal reproducible sample that shows the problem
      and attach it below between the lines with the backticks.

      To create it you can use `flutter create bug` command and update the `main.dart` file.

      Alternatively, you can use https://dartpad.dev/
      which is capable of creating and running small Flutter apps.

      Without this we will unlikely be able to progress on the issue, and because of that
      we regretfully will have to close it.
-->

```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';
import 'package:google_maps_flutter/google_maps_flutter.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const TestApp());
}

class TestApp extends StatelessWidget {
  const TestApp({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      theme: ThemeData.dark(useMaterial3: true),
      home: HomePage(),
    );
  }
}

class HomePage extends StatelessWidget {
  const HomePage({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Scaffold(
      body: Center(
        child: ElevatedButton(
          onPressed: () {
            Navigator.push(
              context,
              MaterialPageRoute(
                builder: (context) => GoogleMapsPage(),
              ),
            );
          },
          child: Text("Go to google maps"),
        ),
      ),
    );
  }
}

class GoogleMapsPage extends StatelessWidget {
  const GoogleMapsPage({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return GoogleMap(
      //random camera position
      initialCameraPosition: CameraPosition(
        target: LatLng(37.4221, 122.0841),
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

</details>

Tho the bug may be because I use a preview of Flutter 3.7

Hello everyone, I just upgraded `google_sign_in` from `6.2.2` to `7.1.0` and encountered this error:

`GoogleSignInException(code GoogleSignInExceptionCode.clientConfigurationError, serverClientId must be provided on Android, null`

I managed to fix this issue by providing my web client ID instead of the Android one.

What I don't understand is that in the [integration docs](https://pub.dev/packages/google_sign_in_android#integration), it stated that I don't need `serverClientId` if I already provided `google-services.json`

> If you are not using google-services.json, you need to pass the client ID of the web application you registered as the serverClientId when initialising the GoogleSignIn instance.

Hope anyone can help me understand more about this issue and clear up any misunderstanding on my side.

Thank you.

### Steps to reproduce

Try to write a test that involves e.g. `SharedPreferencesWithCache`

### Expected results

I'd expect the APIs to offer something similar to what the legacy API do, e.g. `SharedPreferences.setMockInitialValues`.
Or, alternatively, a way to set the underlying platform to `.inMemory` (similarly to [this](https://github.com/flutter/packages/blob/1642c3a66759a5388caefc9b5dc38691f3fa5098/packages/shared_preferences/shared_preferences/test/shared_preferences_async_test.dart#L670)).

### Actual results
I tried using the old `.setMockInitialValues` and then opening a `SharedPreferencesWithCache` instance, but this leads to
```
Bad state: The SharedPreferencesAsyncPlatform instance must be set.
```
... as there's no way to access those APIs for me!

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

```dart
import "package:flutter_test/flutter_test.dart";
import "package:shared_preferences/shared_preferences.dart";

void main() {
  setUp(() {
    SharedPreferences.setMockInitialValues({});
  });
  test("let folks mock the new shared prefs apis", () {
    final prefs = SharedPreferencesWithCache.create(
      cacheOptions: const SharedPreferencesWithCacheOptions(),
    );
    expectLater(prefs, completes);
  });
}
```

</details>

## Steps to Reproduce ``` flutter create -t module --org com.example.a library_a cd library_a flutter pub add android_intent_plus flutter build aar cd .. flutter create -t module --org com.example.b library_b cd library_a flutter pub add android_intent_plus // Open pubspec.yaml and change android_intent_plus to 1.0.1 flutter build aar --build-number=2.0 ``` Add library aars to an android project (I used a new android project) You can find Gradle scan here https://scans.gradle.com/s/k2kgkmqjntcay android_intent_plus versions are the same as the root library version. 1.0 and 2.0. Library_b overrides the library_a's android_intent_plus dependency because 2.0 is higher than 1.0. But in reality, library_b should have a lower version with 1.0.1 and library_a should have android_intent_plus with version 3.1.5. (or the latest version of android_intent_plus) Previously reported issue. https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/115732 Please find flutter projects here. [Archive.zip](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/files/10264072/Archive.zip) - Open the zip, and build projects as described. - library_a -> flutter build aar --build-number=1.0 - library_b -> flutter build aar --build-number=2.0 - Integrate libraries into a new android project Build the project. The project will fail with the following error -> https://stackoverflow.com/questions/74857653/adding-multiple-flutter-library-modules-fails-build-with-duplicate-class. Build with multiple flutter projects should also compile without problem but the build fail is a different case. This issue is intended to manifest the library version issue. As seen in the screenshot, library_a and library_b brings android_intent_plus with their own versions instead of 1.0.1 and 3.1.5. built aar files' pom have following dependencies. library_a ``` io.flutter.plugins.androidintent android_intent_plus 1.0 compile ``` library_a ``` io.flutter.plugins.androidintent android_intent_plus 2.0 compile ``` # Expected behaviour - library_a should request android_intent_plus with 3.1.5 - library_b should request android_intent_plus with 1.0.1 when they added to a grade build.

Essentially all other packages have unit tests that run in less than a minute; flutter_migrate is doing something more like integration tests, and the tests take 10 minutes. We should look into slimming them down; that's way too long for unit tests to take, and is causing some timeout issues in certain cases.

I'm attempting to upgrade the `in_app_purchase` from 0.5.x to 1.0.x but it seems that the purchase restoration user flow that we are currently using on iOS is no longer achievable with the newer version of the plugin. I'd appreciate guidance on how to achieve our current functionality with `in_app_purchase` 1.0 or (alternatively) what is the recommended user experience for purchase restoration on iOS that is compatible with `in_app_purchase` 1.0.

Currently, our application works like this:
1. User taps "restore purchases" and the application starts showing a progress indicator.
2. Behind the scenses, `InAppPurchase.instance.queryPastPurchases()` is called.
3. When the call finishes, the progress indicator is hidden, and the return value is inspected.
4. If current purchases were returned: they are restored.
5. **If no current purchases were returned: a message is shown letting the user know that there was nothing to restore and suggesting making a new purchase.**

Now `queryPastPurchases()` has been removed. `restorePurchases()` can be used instead, but it doesn't return anything. So it seems the app won't be able to react when there was nothing to restore. The user won't get any feedback after tapping the button, which doesn't seem user-friendly at all. From the user's standpoint, it looks like that app just ignores the taps (because nothing happens), so it looks like the app is broken.

I'd like at least **one** of the following:
1. A way to know that nothing was restored by `restorePurchases()`
2. A way to know that there is nothing to restore, even before calling `restorePurchases()`
3. A recommendation for a different purchase restoration user experience on iOS that is at lest as user-friendly as our current one and compatible with `in_app_purchase` 1.0.

When adding restricted scopes to unverified oauth, google sign in loads forever on Android.  Works in iOS. 

Steps to reproduce: 
1) Add unverified restricted scope in Google Console
2) Add unverified restricted scope in app
3) Sign in with Google on Android (result: loads forever)

Unverified scopes should show unverified oauth screen and allowed to proceed with sign in.

  Future<FirebaseUser> login() async {
    final GoogleSignInAccount googleSignInAccount = await googleSignIn.signIn();
    final GoogleSignInAuthentication googleSignInAuthentication = await googleSignInAccount.authentication;

    final AuthCredential credential = GoogleAuthProvider.getCredential(
      accessToken: googleSignInAuthentication.accessToken,
      idToken: googleSignInAuthentication.idToken,
    );
    // You'll need this token to call the Youtube API. It expires every 30 minutes.
    final token = googleSignInAuthentication.accessToken;

    final AuthResult authResult = await auth.signInWithCredential(credential);
    final FirebaseUser user = authResult.user;
    assert(!user.isAnonymous);
    assert(await user.getIdToken() != null);

    final FirebaseUser currentUser = await auth.currentUser();
    assert(user.uid == currentUser.uid);

    return currentUser; }`

### Steps to reproduce

2. Add an `AutofillGroup` with 2 `TextField`s (a `Form` with `TextFormField`s has the same behavior)
3. Run the project in Chrome
4. Attempt to use a password manager to autofill the inputs

**I've included a sample repo**: https://github.com/timmywil/flutter_test_autofill

Fields should be filled in when selecting credentials.

### Actual results

### Steps to reproduce

Very often, it is not possible to inspect variable values by hovering over variable names while in a Flutter web debug session. The actual variable value is not displayed as it would be expected. Instead, a tooltip displaying the type of the variable is displayed, just as if the debugger wasn't running.

1. Create a Flutter web application using flutter create, then add an `async` function somewhere. Call it from, eg., the `incrementCounter()` implementation. Just print something out in this async function.
2. Place a breakpoint on the `print` line and start debugging
3. When you reach your breakpoint, try hovering a member variable name in the source code.




### Expected results

The variable value should be displayed.

### Actual results

The value of the variable is not displayed.

When the problem occurs, if you type the variable name in the debug console, you will see:

```
> image

Fixed an issue #169659

This PR improves the StretchingOverscrollIndicator to better match native Android behavior.

- Previously, the stretch effect worked well only for slow dragging, and during fast flings it was absent or felt clipped.
- Implemented a Simulation-based animation that responds naturally to both slow drags and high-velocity flings.
- The result closely resembles the native Android overscroll behavior while maintaining Flutter's performance characteristics.

This change ensures that momentum-based gestures produce a more natural and intuitive overscroll experience, especially for users accustomed to native Android scroll views.

Refiling of #169273 (reverted in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/170034), which is a refiling of #164094, which itself is a rebase of #159675.

This PR adds bundling support for the experimental dart data asset feature: Dart packages with hooks can now emit data assets which the flutter tool will bundle.

It relies on flutter's existing asset bundling mechanism (e.g. entries in AssetManifest.json, DevFS syncing in reload/restart, ...).

The support is added under an experimental flag (similar to the existing native assets experimental flag).

Also, kNativeAssets is removed to also bundle data assets on flutter build bundle.

The chrome sandbox is disabled as per #165664.

### Steps to reproduce

Used https://github.com/MohanedZekry/flutter-go-router-example to reproduce:

1. Replace home_screen.dart:

```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

class HomeScreen extends StatelessWidget {
  const HomeScreen({Key? key}) : super(key: key);

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Center(
      child: PopupMenuButton<String>(
        icon: const Icon(Icons.menu, color: Colors.white),
        elevation: 16.0,
        shape: const RoundedRectangleBorder(
          borderRadius: BorderRadius.all(Radius.circular(4.0)),
        ),
        position: PopupMenuPosition.under,
        offset: const Offset(0, 16),
        itemBuilder: (BuildContext context) {
          return [
            const PopupMenuItem<String>(
              value: 'item1',
              child: Text('Item 1'),
            ),
          ];
        },
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

2. Open PopUpMenu
3. Navigate to any BottomMenuItem (other than HOME)

### Expected results

When navigating to another tab, the popup should automatically close.

### Actual results

The popup does not close and remains visible.

### Steps to reproduce

Used https://github.com/MohanedZekry/flutter-go-router-example to reproduce:

1. Replace `home_screen.dart`:
```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

class HomeScreen extends StatelessWidget {
  const HomeScreen({Key? key}) : super(key: key);

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Center(
      child: PopupMenuButton<String>(
        icon: const Icon(Icons.menu, color: Colors.white),
        elevation: 16.0,
        shape: const RoundedRectangleBorder(
          borderRadius: BorderRadius.all(Radius.circular(4.0)),
        ),
        position: PopupMenuPosition.under,
        offset: const Offset(0, 16),
        itemBuilder: (BuildContext context) {
          return [
            const PopupMenuItem<String>(
              value: 'item1',
              child: Text('Item 1'),
            ),
          ];
        },
      ),
    );
  }
}
```
2. Open PopUpMenu
3. Navigate to any BottomMenuItem (other than HOME)

### Expected results

Pop up should dismiss without error
Go_Router navigation should own the WidgetTree and navigate

### Actual results

App shows red screen with following error, Go_Router navigation occurs beneath:

`════════ Exception caught by widgets library ═══════════════════════════════════
The following assertion was thrown building LayoutBuilder:
This widget has been unmounted, so the State no longer has a context (and should be considered defunct).
Consider canceling any active work during "dispose" or using the "mounted" getter to determine if the State is still active.`

On app startup, when the work to start the engine, launch the app, and set the Dart code running is serialized on the platform thread, the time to first interactable frame takes longer. This issue tracks investigating and mitigating the regression.

b/373761573

### Use case

i'm building an app that send bulk sms's and i want to send them by segments periodically, and this can be achieved using foreground or background services and i have to use MethodChannels for that.

### Proposal

make MethodChannels from any isolate

Refiling of #169273, which itself is a rebase of #159675

This PR adds bundling support for the experimental dart data asset feature: Dart packages with hooks can now emit data assets which the flutter tool will bundle.

It relies on flutter's existing asset bundling mechanism (e.g. entries in AssetManifest.json, DevFS syncing in reload/restart, ...).

The support is added under an experimental flag (similar to the existing native assets experimental flag).

Also, kNativeAssets is removed to also bundle data assets on flutter build bundle.

The chrome sandbox is disabled as per #165664.

4. do hot reload (and you will see the "bad state" issue)

### Steps to reproduce

When I use a normal `GestureDetector` I get my terminal filled with warnings on the motion event, such as this:

```
W/MotionEvent-JNI(11414): android_view_MotionEvent_nativeGetPointerCount: -1
```


### Expected results

I expect the touch events of the `GestureDetector` to not trigger any warning

### Actual results

I get spammed with the following warning whenever I touch the `GestureDetector`:
```
W/MotionEvent-JNI(11414): android_view_MotionEvent_nativeGetPointerCount: -1
```

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

The code needed to reproduce this error is a simple `StatefulWidget` with a single `GestureDetector` button:
```dart
class TestGraphics extends StatefulWidget {
  const TestGraphics({super.key});

  @override
  State<TestGraphics> createState() => _TestGraphicsState();
}

class _TestGraphicsState extends State<TestGraphics> {
  @override
  void initState() {
    super.initState();
  }

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Scaffold(
      body: Column(
        mainAxisAlignment: MainAxisAlignment.center,
        children: [
          GestureDetector(
            onTap: () {
              print("TEST");
            },
            child: Container(color: Colors.amber, width: 100, height: 100),
          ),
         ],
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

</details>

When running a fresh Flutter web project (flutter create) on Flutter 3.35.2, I get the following error repeatedly in the terminal:

DebugService: Error serving requestsError: Unsupported operation: Cannot send Null

The app works fine in the browser, but this error pollutes the debug console and seems to come from the Dart/Flutter VM service

## Problem

Since Flutter 3.35, `MediaQuery.of(context)` inside CupertinoNavigationBar components (trailing, leading, middle, etc.) returns `Size(0.0, 0.0)` instead of the correct screen dimensions. This regression breaks responsive logic and layout decisions made within navigation bar components.

## Root Cause

The issue occurs because CupertinoNavigationBar components wrap their child widgets with `MediaQuery` widgets that only provide `textScaler` data using `MediaQueryData(textScaler: ...)`. When creating a `MediaQueryData` with only specific properties, all other properties default to their initial values, causing `size` to default to `Size.zero`.

Affected components:
- Leading widget
- Trailing widget 
- Middle widget
- Back chevron
- Back label
- Large title
- Bottom widget

## Solution

Replace `MediaQueryData()` constructors with `MediaQuery.of(context).copyWith()` to preserve all existing MediaQuery properties (size, padding, devicePixelRatio, etc.) while only modifying the text scaling behavior.

## Changes

### Core Fix
- Modified 6 `MediaQueryData` constructor calls in `packages/flutter/lib/src/cupertino/nav_bar.dart`
- Preserves all inherited MediaQuery properties while maintaining text scaling limits
- Ensures `size`, `padding`, `devicePixelRatio` and other properties are not reset to defaults

### Testing
- Added comprehensive test suite with 3 focused test cases in `packages/flutter/test/cupertino/nav_bar_test.dart`
- Tests verify MediaQuery size preservation in trailing/leading widgets
- Regression test specifically prevents Size(0,0) from returning
- Tests are minimal and focused on the core issue

## Impact

### Fixed Issues
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).size returns correct screen dimensions
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).padding returns correct safe area padding  
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).devicePixelRatio returns correct pixel ratio
- ✅ Responsive navigation bar components work correctly
- ✅ No impact on existing text scaling behavior

### Compatibility
- ✅ Backward compatible - no breaking changes
- ✅ No impact on Material design widgets
- ✅ All existing CupertinoNavigationBar functionality preserved
- ✅ Performance neutral - same number of MediaQuery widgets

## Testing Instructions

To verify the fix:

```dart
CupertinoNavigationBar(
  trailing: Builder(
    builder: (context) {
      final size = MediaQuery.of(context).size;
      print('Size: $size'); // Should print actual screen size, not Size(0.0, 0.0)
      return Icon(CupertinoIcons.info);
    },
  ),
)
```

In https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/171391 we had a situation where a number of analysis failures only showed up in post-submit when updating the macOS min OS version used for our deprecation detection. On further investigation, it was because the `master` test (which runs in both presubmit and postsubmit) passed, but the `stable` version of the test (which only runs in postsubmit) failed.

Maybe some auto-migration that happens on `master` invalidated the test in some way? This needs more investigation.

### Steps to reproduce



I encountered a texture flickering bug when using external textures for video playback on iOS platform. I've prepared a demo that consistently reproduces this issue on Flutter 3.35.1.



**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Clone the demo repository
2. Run on iOS device with Flutter 3.35.1
3. Observe texture flickering (no need to click PlayAll)



### Expected results

Video should play smoothly without texture flickering.

### Actual results

Texture flickering occurs during video playback when using external textures.

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>


**Demo repository:** https://github.com/qpalwo/flutter_flash_screen

**Key changes:** https://github.com/qpalwo/flutter_flash_screen/commit/1f00260e3781119ad04bfbc6617a9b28a98af523

**Suspected root cause:**
I suspect this issue is related to PR https://github.com/flutter/engine/pull/57020. After changing `keep_alive_frame_count` to 0, the issue no longer reproduces.

**Analysis:**
Upon examining the related logic, I believe the problem may be caused by improper reuse of the RenderTargetCache during YUV to RGB conversion.

### Use case

I want to be able to open/close menu of `DropdownMenu` manually.

### Proposal

Add optional `MenuController` parameter to `DropdownMenu`.  

Currently, in `DropdownMenu` state, the variable `MenuController _controller` is assigned with `MenuController()`.  
Make it `widget.menuController ?? MenuController()`.

2. Convert to String
3. Execute textPainter.layout()
4. Execute textPainter.computeLineMetrics()
5. do something

class _MyHomePageState extends State<MyHomePage> {

      debugShowCheckedModeBanner: false,
      home: Scaffold(

          child: MaterialButton(

            child: const Text(

              style: TextStyle(color: Colors.white),
            ),
          ),
        ),
      ),
    );

    final result = await FilePicker.platform.pickFiles(allowMultiple: false,
        type: FileType.custom,
        allowedExtensions: ['txt']
    );

    // if no file is picked
    if (result == null) return;

    if (result.files.isNotEmpty) {
      final file = File(result.files.first.path.toString());
      Uint8List? fileBytes = file.readAsBytesSync();
      String temp = await CharsetConverter.decode("utf-8", fileBytes);

      final textSpan = TextSpan(
        text: temp,
        style: const TextStyle(
          color: Colors.black,
          fontSize: 10,
        ),
      );
      final textPainter = TextPainter(

        textDirection: TextDirection.ltr,
      );

      List<LineMetrics> lines = textPainter.computeLineMetrics();
      //double currentPageBottom = 623.2727272727273;

      for (int i = 0; i < lines.length; i++) {
        final line = lines[i];

        //do something
      }
    }
  }
}

### Steps to reproduce

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Perform a full reinstall of Android Studio and the Android SDK on macOS.
2. Delete the global `.gradle` cache (`rm -rf ~/.gradle`).
3. Run `flutter doctor -v` to confirm a healthy environment.
4. Create a brand new, unmodified Flutter project: `flutter create my_app`.
5. Attempt to build for Android: `cd my_app` and then `flutter run`.

### Expected Results
The new, unmodified project should compile and run successfully on an Android device.

### Actual Results
The build fails with a Kotlin script compilation error in `android/settings.gradle.kts`:
`e: .../settings.gradle.kts:6:26: Unresolved reference: Properties`

---

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Run `flutter create bug`.
2. Override provideFlutterEngine and configureFlutterEngine in MainActivity (`android/app/src/main/kotlin/com/example/bug/MainActivity.kt`) to return a persistent engine (and import `android.content.Context` and `io.flutter.embedding.engine.FlutterEngine`):
    ```
    override fun provideFlutterEngine(context: Context): FlutterEngine? {
        return provideEngine(this)
    }
    override fun configureFlutterEngine(flutterEngine: FlutterEngine) {
        // do nothing, because the engine was configured in provideEngine
    }
    companion object {
        var engine: FlutterEngine? = null
        fun provideEngine(context: Context): FlutterEngine {
            val eng = engine ?: FlutterEngine(context, emptyArray(), true, false)
            engine = eng
            return eng
        }
    }
    ```
3. This works as expected. The app can be closed and opened again.
4. Now, change the base class of MainActivity from FlutterActivity to FlutterFragmentActivity.
5. Open and close the app. FlutterFragmentActivity destroys the engine on detach. Open the app again. It crashes because provideFlutterEngine provided a destroyed engine.

As a workaround, I created a subclass of FlutterEngine with an overridden, empty destroy method.

## Steps to Reproduce (tested on Android and Web)

1. Execute `flutter run` on the code sample
2. Press the FloatingActionButton
3. Press OK on the DatePickerDialog which is in Input Mode

**Expected results:**
Just like in EntryMode.calendar no Exception will be thrown because selectableDayPredicate is not run after the Dialog returned a value.

**Actual results:** 
Exception is thrown because selectableDayPredicate is run once AFTER the Dialog in EntryMode.input returns the selected date

<details>
<summary>Code sample</summary>

```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const MyApp());
}

class MyApp extends StatelessWidget {
  const MyApp({Key? key}) : super(key: key);

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      title: 'Flutter Demo',
      theme: ThemeData(
        primarySwatch: Colors.blue,
      ),
      home: const MyHomePage(title: 'Flutter Demo Home Page'),
    );
  }
}

class MyHomePage extends StatefulWidget {
  const MyHomePage({Key? key, required this.title}) : super(key: key);

  final String title;

  @override
  State<MyHomePage> createState() => _MyHomePageState();
}

class _MyHomePageState extends State<MyHomePage> {
  DateTime? dateTime;

  void _changeDate() {
    dateTime = null;
    showDatePicker(
        context: context,
        initialDate: DateTime.now(),
        firstDate: DateTime.now().subtract(const Duration(days: 10)),
        lastDate: DateTime.now(),
        initialEntryMode: DatePickerEntryMode.input,
        selectableDayPredicate: (date) {
          if (dateTime == null) {
            print("$date is selectable");
            return true;
          }
          if (DateUtils.dateOnly(dateTime!) == date) {
            print("$date is NOT selectable");
            return false;
          }
          print("$date is selectable");
          return true;
        }).then((value) {
      setState(() {
        dateTime = value;
        print("#showDatePicker() returned with $dateTime");
      });
    });
  }

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Scaffold(
      appBar: AppBar(
        title: Text(widget.title),
      ),
      body: Center(
        child: Column(
          mainAxisAlignment: MainAxisAlignment.center,
          children: <Widget>[
            const Text(
              'selectedDate:',
            ),
            Text(
              '$dateTime',
              style: Theme.of(context).textTheme.headline4,
            ),
          ],
        ),
      ),
      floatingActionButton: FloatingActionButton(
        onPressed: _changeDate,
        tooltip: 'change Date',
        child: const Icon(Icons.edit_calendar),
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

</details>

In some cases it is necessary to run tests repeatedly to reproduce flakiness. To achieve this, few changes are needed:
- Disable automatic device reboot logic (otherwise it interrupts the test run)
- Document instructions how to locally run tests repeatedly

flutter widget-preview start

### Steps to reproduce

We could only repro this on `3.32.8` and not at `3.35.1`. We are simply opening this issue so that if the Android team wants to revisit this and add some tests to make sure this fix wasn't accidental. We could not find any related issues so this is why we are opening this one.

1. Clone https://github.com/FMorschel/flutter_workspace
This project is a pub workspace with two `flutter create -e <project>` projects, and one of them has a dependency, but the other does not.
See that `two` has a dependency on `wearable_buttons` plugin (but any plugin where the `minSDK` or `ndkVersion` or similar is higher than the Flutter default will have the same problem).
2. Run `two` on an Android device/emulator and see that everything works fine
3. Try to run `one` on an Android device/emulator and see that it also warns about `ndkVersion` and `minSDK`, but it has no dependency on that plugin.

We have a similar case in our company. The problem is that we actually have a pub workspace with our own packages and six apps. Only one of our apps requires the use of a plugin with a higher `minSDK`. Our other apps need to upgrade these values even though they are not using those packages.

We are using pub workspace to simplify our dependency management and improve our IDE performance, but this bug prevents us from doing so.

### Expected results

I expected to be able to run either app, as the repro above is.

### Actual results

While `two` does run (because it has the dependencies we have manually increased the above-discussed values), `one` doesn't.

Fixes https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/173065

### What was changed:
- **Added accessibility announcements** to SnackBar content. Now, when a SnackBar appears, its content will be announced for screen reader users using `SemanticsService`.

### Why this is important:
- **Accessibility**: Ensures users with visual impairments can hear SnackBar content, enhancing the user experience for a broader audience.

### Related Issue:
- Fixes issue [#173065](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/173065) regarding accessibility for SnackBars.

### Steps to reproduce

**Steps to Reproduce**

Create a new Flutter project with targetSdkVersion and compileSdkVersion set to 35 in android/app/build.gradle.

Use the provided minimal code example, which includes a Scaffold with SafeArea wrapping a TextField and prints MediaQuery padding values.'

Run the app on an Android 9 (API 28) or Android 10 (API 29) emulator or device (e.g., Pixel 3 XL emulator with notch enabled).

Tap the TextField to open the keyboard.

**Observe the following:**

Widgets are obscured by the keyboard (e.g., TextField goes behind the keyboard).

SafeArea does not apply correct padding to avoid the status bar or navigation bar.

MediaQuery.of(context).padding.bottom and MediaQuery.of(context).padding.top return incorrect values (e.g., EdgeInsets.zero or unexpected values).



### Expected results

SafeArea should apply appropriate padding to ensure content is not obscured by the status bar, navigation bar, or keyboard.

MediaQuery.of(context).padding.top should reflect the status bar height (including notch, if present).

MediaQuery.of(context).padding.bottom should reflect the navigation bar height.

MediaQuery.of(context).viewInsets.bottom should reflect the keyboard height when the keyboard is open.

Widgets (e.g., TextField) should remain visible above the keyboard, with SafeArea adjusting the layout accordingly.



### Actual results

**On Android 9 (API 28) and Android 10 (API 29):**

SafeArea does not prevent content from being obscured by the status bar or navigation bar.

Widgets (e.g., TextField) are hidden behind the keyboard when it opens.

MediaQuery.of(context).padding.top and MediaQuery.of(context).padding.bottom often return EdgeInsets.zero or incorrect values.

MediaQuery.of(context).viewInsets.bottom does not update correctly to reflect the keyboard height (remains 0.0 or returns inconsistent values).

### Code sample

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const MyApp());
}

class MyApp extends StatelessWidget {
  const MyApp({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      home: const MyHomePage(),
    );
  }
}

class MyHomePage extends StatelessWidget {
  const MyHomePage({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    // Print MediaQuery padding for debugging
    print('Padding: ${MediaQuery.of(context).padding}');
    print('ViewInsets: ${MediaQuery.of(context).viewInsets}');

    return Scaffold(
      resizeToAvoidBottomInset: false, // Prevent resizing when keyboard appears
      appBar: AppBar(title: const Text('SafeArea & MediaQuery Issue')),
      body: SafeArea(
        top: true,
        bottom: true,
        child: Column(
          mainAxisAlignment: MainAxisAlignment.spaceBetween,
          children: [
            const Text('This should stay visible above the keyboard'),
            TextField(
              decoration: const InputDecoration(
                border: OutlineInputBorder(),
                hintText: 'Type here',
              ),
              onChanged: (value) {
                // Rebuild to check MediaQuery updates
                print('Padding: ${MediaQuery.of(context).padding}');
                print('ViewInsets: ${MediaQuery.of(context).viewInsets}');
              },
            ),
            const Text('This should stay visible above the navigation bar'),
          ],
        ),
      ),
    );
  }
}

## Description

This PR fixes DropdownMenu filtering.
The implementation choice is to not rely on storing the selected index and to store the selected value instead.

## Related Issue

Fixes [DropdownMenu filtering is broken](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/174609)

## Tests

Adds 1 test.

## Issues
 - Fixes #174609

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add package dependencies:
   - `webview_flutter: ^4.13.0`
   - `webview_flutter_wkwebview: ^3.23.0`
2. Run the provided code sample on iPhone device/simulator with iOS 26
3. **Make sure the `input` is not focused**
4. Long press and hold on the text field in the web view to open the magnifier  
   - I am using https://pub.dev/ as an example but it happens on any input field
4. Release the touch
   - This will result in a crash

### Expected results

The magnifier should be dismissed.

### Actual results

App crashes.

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

```dart
import 'dart:async';

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';
import 'package:webview_flutter/webview_flutter.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const MyApp());
}

class MyApp extends StatefulWidget {
  const MyApp({super.key});

  @override
  State<MyApp> createState() => _MyAppState();
}

class _MyAppState extends State<MyApp> {
  late final controller = WebViewController();

  @override
  void initState() {
    super.initState();
    unawaited(loadPage());
  }

  Future<void> loadPage() async {
    final uri = Uri.parse('https://pub.dev');
    await controller.loadRequest(uri);
  }

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      title: 'Flutter Demo',
      theme: ThemeData(
        colorScheme: ColorScheme.fromSeed(seedColor: Colors.deepPurple),
      ),
      home: Scaffold(
        body: SafeArea(
          child: WebViewWidget(
            controller: controller,
          ),
        ),
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

</details>

## Description

This PR fixes IconButton icon color resolution. 

## Before

The IconButton.color property does not take precedence over the ambient `IconButtonTheme`

## After

The IconButton.color property overrides the ambient `IconButtonTheme`.

## Related Issue

Fixes [SnackBar closeIconColor does not respect widget override](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/174472)
Fixes [IconButton.color is overidden by IconButtonTheme](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/174511)  

## Tests

Adds 1 test.

### Steps to reproduce

1. depend on a flutter package with assets via dependency_overrides only.
2. Attempt to use an asset from that package
3. Asset is unable to be found

This worked on previous Flutter versions, but has broken in 3.35. I believe this is related to fixes made for https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/160142

### Expected results

The asset should be able to be found

### Actual results

The asset cannot be found.

The licenses check doesn't seem to be working (for the web engine at least). These two PRs:

- https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/174587
- https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/174588

introduced new source files.

In the past, the licenses check would've failed because we forgot to add the new files to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/engine/src/flutter/ci/licenses_golden/licenses_flutter

Add headers to proxy rules

Context https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/140112#discussion_r1432554426

Once 12 months have passed since dart-code has shipped to stable code using the new "platformTypes" it should be safe to delete this.

### Steps to reproduce

I'm trying to support auto-attaching the debugger to the emulator on Firebase Studio for a better experience. This involves running `flutter attach` for the emulator when the editor opens. However, we don't know if the app that Firebase Studio is launching is already up and running, so it's possible we will run the command while it's still launching.

`flutter attach` _appears_ to wait for the app to start, however at the last moment it throws "Failed to start Dart
Development Service" instead of attaching. Attaching a few seconds later works fine.

To repro:

- Open two terminal Windows in a Flutter project folder
- Start an Android emulator
- Run `flutter run -d emulator` in one terminal
- While the app is building, run `flutter attach -d emulator` in the other terminal




### Expected results

Flutter should attach to the device the same way it does if the command is run slightly later.

### Actual results

The `attach` command will fail:

```
Waiting for a connection from Flutter on sdk gphone64 x86 64...
Error connecting to the service protocol: failed to connect to
http://127.0.0.1:55609/ERoNfHtDZ2E=/ DartDevelopmentServiceException: Failed to start Dart
Development Service
```

However running the command again succeeds.

Note: Sometimes the `flutter run` process actually throws the error, and the `attach` version succeeds and ends up connected!

### Code sample

N/A, any Flutter app will do for testing.

### Screenshots or Video

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7021672b-0982-4992-ab83-d21763772d68

### Steps to reproduce Hey there, there seems to be an issue with Pixel devices on which the screen resolution can be changed (Pixel 6 Pro, 7 Pro, 8 Pro, 9 Pro) and when having set the font and general screen scaling to lowest, while also using the old 3-button-navigation, not the gesture-navigation. I got a report and screenshots from a Pixel 7 Pro user and am able to reproduce this issue with a Pixel 9 Pro, but not on the Pixel 6, presumably because it doesn't have the screen scaling setting. When changing the resolution to 'High resolution" instead of 'Full resolution', setting font and ui scale to the lowest setting and then opening up a bottom sheet with a Syncfusion Chart (https://pub.dev/packages/syncfusion_flutter_charts) in it (I'm not sure whether the bottom sheet has to feature a syncfusion chart or if it can be any bottom sheet, we have multiple bottom sheets and was only able to reproduce it on one with a syncfusion chart), closing the sheet, going to the homescreen, going back to app, will lead to the softkeys aligning to the left side of the screen. Then when going to the homescreen will cause some resolution shift shortly and then bug the keys out fully and they will move to the height of the homescreen dock, to the right. When going to the app again, the keys will move to the bottom, but still at the right and the most recent apps/docks will appear in the navigation bar (I'm fairly sure this is the tablet mode navigation bar for big screen devices). This also seems to result in other apps to be scaled wrong. It seems like the lowered resolution, together with scaling down the ui (and maybe something to do with syncfusion) will cause the phone to do wrong calculations and end up in tablet ui mode. I'm not sure if this is a fault on flutter side, our side, syncfusion side or maybe even pixel side. ### Expected results Usually the app should just be scaled according to the user settings and the ui should not switch to tablet-mode ### Actual results the system ui will switch to some sort of tablet mode ### Code sample

Request to add a list item on the breaking changes for Flutter V3.35 as listed [here](https://docs.flutter.dev/release/breaking-changes)

The following item from the Flutter Changelog seems to have caused a breaking change:
Add flag to exclude focus for hidden children in Visibility, maintainFocusability. Set maintainFocusability to false in IndexedStack by @skimm3 in [159133](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/159133)

To get the same working as in previous Flutter versions you now have to manually set maintainFocusability to true. In this case the default value results in different behaviour from the previous version.

For example when using an invisible text field to allow for input being rendered in a way which TextField doesn't allow for you'd use something alike (with a way to set focus on the field):
```dart
            Visibility(
              visible: false,
              maintainState: true,
              child:TextField(/****/),
              ),
```
This used to work but now one has to add `maintainFocusability: true,` to get the same result.

It would be useful to have a mention on the breaking changes which says something alike: Visibility Widgets relying on being able to focus a child element of said widget now require the new parameter `maintainFocusability: true,` to be set.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Connect headphones to your device
2. Under phone settings -> **_Sounds & Haptics_** set **_Ringtone and Alerts_** to the max volume
3. Open a Flutter app using `CupertinoPicker` and start scrolling

Tested in release mode on an iPhone 14 Pro (iOS 26 public beta)
and iPhone XR (iOS 18.1.1)

### Expected results

The ticking sound plays at a reasonable volume through the headphones or not at all, like the stock clock app on iOS  

### Actual results

The ticking sound plays at the max volume through the headphones which is very uncomfortable

### Code sample

```dart
import 'package:flutter/cupertino.dart';

void main() => runApp(MaterialApp(home: HomeScreen()));

class HomeScreen extends StatelessWidget {

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Scaffold(
      body: Center(
        child: CupertinoTimerPicker(
          onTimerDurationChanged: (_) {},
        ),
      ),
    );
  }
}

### Steps to reproduce The TabBar widget automatically generates accessibility labels in the format "Tab 1 of 7" and there's no way to override or customise these labels. This creates accessibility issues when developers need specific, meaningful labels for their tabs. ## Current Behavior When using TabBar with Tab widgets, the accessibility system automatically generates labels like: "Tab 1 of 7" "Tab 2 of 7" etc. These automatic labels cannot be overridden, even when using Semantics widgets or excludeSemantics: true. ## Current Attempts to Fix 1. Wrapping Tab in Semantics: Doesn't work because TabBar overrides the semantics 2. Using excludeSemantics: Doesn't prevent TabBar's automatic labeling 3. Custom TabBar implementation: Requires rebuilding the entire TabBar functionality ## Impact Accessibility Compliance: Apps cannot meet accessibility requirements when they need specific labels User Experience: Screen readers announce confusing "Tab 1 of 7" instead of meaningful labels Development Overhead: Developers must create custom TabBar implementations Related Issues #12432: "Customize a11y for TabBars" (closed, but issue persists) PS: The suggested solution was to add a child parameter to TabBar, but this is also not working. ### Expected results Developers should be able to provide custom accessibility labels for tabs, either through: 1. A label parameter on Tab widgets 2. The ability to wrap Tab widgets in Semantics widgets 3. A callback to customize accessibility labels ### Actual results When using TabBar with Tab widgets, the accessibility system automatically generates labels like: "Tab 1 of 7" "Tab 2 of 7" etc. These automatic labels cannot be overridden, even when using Semantics widgets or excludeSemantics: true. ### Code sample
Code sample ```dart import 'package:flutter/material.dart'; void main() { runApp(const MyApp()); } class MyApp extends StatefulWidget { const MyApp({super.key}); @override State createState() => _MyAppState(); } class _MyAppState extends State with TickerProviderStateMixin { late TabController _tabController; @override void initState() { super.initState(); _tabController = TabController(length: 3, vsync: this); } @override void dispose() { _tabController.dispose(); super.dispose(); } @override Widget build(BuildContext context) { return MaterialApp( debugShowCheckedModeBanner: false, home: Scaffold( appBar: AppBar(title: const Text('TabBar Bug Demo')), body: Column( children: [ TabBar( controller: _tabController, tabs: const [ Tab(text: 'Tab 1'), Tab(text: 'Tab 2'), Tab(text: 'Tab 3'), ], ), Expanded( child: TabBarView( controller: _tabController, children: const [ Center(child: Text('Content 1')), Center(child: Text('Content 2')), Center(child: Text('Content 3')), ], ), ), ], ), ), ); } } ```

### Steps to reproduce If there are some text boxes: When comparing the green box to the blue box using _getBoundingBox, the green box will be sorted after the blue box. This result must be wrong. Using xx.boundingBoxes.first seems to be correct. ### Expected results The blue box order is behind green box. ### Actual results The green box order is behind blue box. ### Code sample
Code sample ```dart @override Comparator get compareOrder => _compareScreenOrder; static int _compareScreenOrder(Selectable a, Selectable b) { // Attempt to sort the selectables under a [_SelectableTextContainerDelegate] // by the top left rect. final Rect rectA = MatrixUtils.transformRect(a.getTransformTo(null), a.boundingBoxes.first); final Rect rectB = MatrixUtils.transformRect(b.getTransformTo(null), b.boundingBoxes.first); final int result = _compareVertically(rectA, rectB); if (result != 0) { return result; } return _compareHorizontally(rectA, rectB); } ```
### Screenshots or Video When I was in Flutter 3.19.1, this problem occurred because `compareOrder` was not overridden in `Text`. Because of the order problem, the middle part of the copy is not highlighted.
Screenshots / Video demonstration
In the current master branch, the ` Comparator get compareOrder => _compareScreenOrder;` function in the Text class has been overwritten, so the performance is correct. However,` _getBoundingBox` is still used for comparison in `selectable_region.dart`, which has potential risks. ### Logs
Logs ```console [Paste your logs here] ```
### Flutter Doctor output Doctor output is correct.

### Use case

Developers wanting to use the `DropdownMenu` but without the type-to-search of the Material 3 widget.

### Proposal

I propose that the `enableSearch` flag is also passed to the `readOnly` attribute of the underlying `TextField`. Currently it's only used for the search highlight. If we can disable the I-beam cursor and text selection, that would be good as well.

We can tweak the `effectiveMouseCursor` and the `SelectionContainer` for the text field when it does not allow searching.

iOS 14 introduced a system notification when an app pasted from the pasteboard as a security feature.  In iOS 15, Apple is introducing "secure paste", which seems like it will bypass this notification when the paste is initiated by the user.

https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2021/06/apple-advances-its-privacy-leadership-with-ios-15-ipados-15-macos-monterey-and-watchos-8/
https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10085/?time=360

That information about the feature is vague, but it may not be possible for Flutter to implement this, at least for the text selection menu, since Flutter doesn't use the native text selection menu.  If I'm understanding it correctly, tapping on Flutter's "paste" button will always be treated as being initiated by the app, and it will show the notification.

We may be able to support this for the keyboard by receiving whatever "user paste" event Apple creates and sending something along to the framework.

### Steps to reproduce

I’m using a NestedScrollView with a floating SliverAppBar (red header) above a list of rows (random colors). The behavior is correct on iPhone 13/11 and Pixel 4, but on Pixel 8 the header sometimes pops into view incorrectly while scrolling.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the screen with NestedScrollView + floating SliverAppBar (snap: true, float: true) and SliverOverlapAbsorber/Injector.
2. Scroll the list down, then slightly change direction.
3. Observe the header.

Environment:
- Device: Pixel 8 (Android 16)
- Works on: iPhone 13/11, Pixel 4
- Flutter: 3.29.3 (stable)
- Flags: floating: true, snap: true, pinned: false, floatHeaderSlivers: true
- Inner scroll: CustomScrollView with SliverOverlapInjector

### Expected results

When scrolling down, the floating SliverAppBar should hide; it should only appear when scrolling up (or when snap is triggered appropriately).

### Actual results

On Pixel 8, the header intermittently appears (snaps open) even while scrolling down, causing a sudden flicker/pop-in. Sometimes, when scrolling down slightly, the app bar appears unexpectedly.

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

```dart
@override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Container(
      color: ColorTheme.neutral100,
      child: _buildSTOsPageTabWidget(),
    );
  }

  Widget _buildSTOsPageTabWidget() {
    return NestedScrollView(
      floatHeaderSlivers: true,
      controller: _scrollController,
      headerSliverBuilder: (ctx, innerBoxIsScrolled) => [
        SliverOverlapAbsorber(
          handle: NestedScrollView.sliverOverlapAbsorberHandleFor(ctx),
          sliver: SliverAppBar(
            floating: true,
            snap: true,
            forceElevated: innerBoxIsScrolled,
            flexibleSpace: Container(
              height: 139,
              color: Colors.red,
              child: Center(
                child: Text(
                  'Center Title',
                  style: TextStyles.F16W400L04.apply(color: Colors.black),
                ),
              ),
            ),
            backgroundColor: ColorTheme.neutral100,
            elevation: 0,
            toolbarHeight: 139,
          ),
        ),
      ],
      body: Builder(builder: (context) {
        return CustomScrollView(
          // Let NestedScrollView control it
          physics: const ClampingScrollPhysics(), // smoother on Android
          slivers: [
            // MUST be the first sliver of the inner scroll
            SliverOverlapInjector(
              handle: NestedScrollView.sliverOverlapAbsorberHandleFor(context),
            ),
            SliverList.builder(
              itemCount: 1000,
              itemBuilder: (_, i) => Container(
                height: 80,
                color: Color((math.Random().nextDouble() * 0xFFFFFF).toInt())
                    .withValues(alpha: 1.0),
                child: Text(
                  'CELL $i',
                  style: TextStyles.F16W400L04.apply(color: Colors.black),
                ),
              ),
            ),
          ],
        );
      }),
    );
  }
```

</details>

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add `webViewController.runJavaScript('''document.body.innerText='It works!';''')`.
2. Notice red error message.

### Expected results

It should replace the web view content with "It works!".

### Actual results

It shows an error in browser and console:
```
The following UnimplementedError was thrown building RunJavaScript(dirty):
runJavaScript is not implemented on the current platform
```

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';
import 'package:webview_flutter/webview_flutter.dart';
import 'package:webview_flutter_web/webview_flutter_web.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const RunJavaScript());
}

class RunJavaScript extends StatelessWidget {
  const RunJavaScript({super.key});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    var webViewController = WebViewController.fromPlatform(
      WebWebViewController(WebWebViewControllerCreationParams()),
    );

    webViewController.loadHtmlString('''<html><head>
      <title>WebWebView</title>
    </head><body>
      It doesn't work!
    </body></html>''');

    webViewController.runJavaScript('''
      document.body.innerText = 'It works!';
    ''');

    return SizedBox(
      height: 480,
      child: WebViewWidget(controller: webViewController),
    );
  }
}
```

</details>

Reopen of #170775 (closed due to inactivity; however, the issue still persists and I was unable to follow up earlier)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Obtain a Samsung Galaxy S10 (SM-G973N) running Android 12 (Build Number: SP1A.210812.016).
2. Clone [the repository](https://github.com/bc-lee/test-flutter-android-texture) and build the app. I tested with Flutter 3.32.0+ as well as the master branch (commit: 72017e1a06b3d224f0a24575b50d9c3b510e29f9).
3. Run the app on the device and tap the Start button to begin rendering the triangle.

### Expected results

The app should render a red triangle on the screen without any issues.

### Actual results

The triangle is almost not visible due to almost white color.

### Code sample

See the repository above mentioned in the steps to reproduce.

### Screenshots or Video

<details open>
<summary>Screenshots / Video demonstration</summary>

Default:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/41bfac49-7762-4d6d-b916-7fb7f9dd0beb

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b407e5bc-9ea8-434b-b0cf-f0156a8fe432

</details>

### Use case There is `Radio` and `CupertinoRadio` I'd like/need a way to customise `Radio` to change in independent ways - The color of the border. - The background color (always transparent) for now. - The color of the circle in it. - The width of the border. - The size of the circle in it. That would allow me to have different designs or designs that are halfway through material and cupertino. For example (ignore the ugly chosen colors): ### Proposal Add parameter to `Radio` and `RadioThemeData` to be able to set - The color of the border. - The background color (always transparent) for now. - The color of the circle in it. - The width of the border. - The size of the circle in it.

### Use case

I'm trying to use [SweepGradient](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/dart-ui/Gradient/Gradient.sweep.html)

### Proposal

As noted previously https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/23648 SweepGradient's startAngle and endAngle parameters are not well named. Even after reading that issue and experimenting with them, I still don't know exactly how they're supposed to work. With experimentation, I was able to get startAngle and endAngle to do something by setting them to pi/2 and tau-pi/2 (that made it look like the "mirrored" example, but any angle smaller than that seemed to do nothing.

[The documentation](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/dart-ui/Gradient/Gradient.sweep.html) makes it sound like they're just what you'd expect them to be given their names,

> Creates a sweep gradient centered at center that starts at startAngle and ends at endAngle.

> startAngle and endAngle should be provided in radians, with zero radians being the horizontal line to the right of the center and with positive angles going clockwise around the center.

 but as discussed, there's more to know.

The documentation later says

> The behavior before startAngle and after endAngle is described by the tileMode argument. For details, see the [TileMode](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/dart-ui/TileMode.html) enum.

But startAngle and endAngle are actually not mentioned in the TileMode page.
Please add this feature or give me a quick fix so I can select multi_video like multi_image. Thank you.

`Channel stable, 3.32.8`

## Problem

Since Flutter 3.35, `MediaQuery.of(context)` inside CupertinoNavigationBar components (trailing, leading, middle, etc.) returns `Size(0.0, 0.0)` instead of the correct screen dimensions. This regression breaks responsive logic and layout decisions made within navigation bar components.

## Root Cause

The issue was introduced when CupertinoNavigationBar components started wrapping their child widgets with `MediaQuery` widgets that only provided `textScaler` data using `MediaQueryData(textScaler: ...)`. When creating a `MediaQueryData` with only specific properties, all other properties default to their initial values, causing `size` to default to `Size.zero`.

Affected components:
- Leading widget
- Trailing widget 
- Middle widget
- Back chevron
- Back label
- Large title
- Bottom widget

## Solution

Replace `MediaQueryData()` constructors with `MediaQuery.of(context).copyWith()` to preserve all existing MediaQuery properties (size, padding, devicePixelRatio, etc.) while only modifying the text scaling behavior.

## Changes

### Core Fix
- Modified 6 `MediaQueryData` constructor calls in `packages/flutter/lib/src/cupertino/nav_bar.dart`
- Preserves all inherited MediaQuery properties while maintaining text scaling limits
- Ensures `size`, `padding`, `devicePixelRatio` and other properties are not reset to defaults

### Testing
- Added comprehensive test suite with 6 new test cases in `packages/flutter/test/cupertino/nav_bar_test.dart`
- Tests cover MediaQuery size preservation in trailing/leading widgets
- Tests verify MediaQuery padding and devicePixelRatio preservation  
- Tests validate middle widget and large title MediaQuery preservation
- Regression test specifically checking for Size(0,0) prevention
- All existing tests continue to pass (76/76 passing)

## Impact

### Fixed Issues
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).size returns correct screen dimensions
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).padding returns correct safe area padding
- ✅ MediaQuery.of(context).devicePixelRatio returns correct pixel ratio
- ✅ Responsive navigation bar components work correctly
- ✅ No impact on existing text scaling behavior

### Compatibility
- ✅ Backward compatible - no breaking changes
- ✅ No impact on Material design widgets
- ✅ All existing CupertinoNavigationBar functionality preserved
- ✅ Performance neutral - same number of MediaQuery widgets

## Testing Instructions

To verify the fix:

1. Create a CupertinoNavigationBar with trailing/leading widgets
2. Access MediaQuery.of(context).size inside the widget builders
3. Verify size returns actual screen dimensions, not Size(0,0)

```dart
CupertinoNavigationBar(
  trailing: Builder(
    builder: (context) {
      final size = MediaQuery.of(context).size;
      print('Size: $size'); // Should print actual screen size, not Size(0.0, 0.0)
      return Icon(CupertinoIcons.info);
    },
  ),
)
```

## References

- Fixes flutter/flutter#174771
- Component: packages/flutter/lib/src/cupertino/nav_bar.dart
- Test file: packages/flutter/test/cupertino/nav_bar_test.dart

Fixes https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/174579

Bevel and Miter (and later Round) joins were fixed by being more careful about the creation of the vertices so that they have no inherent overdraw, ~but Round joins would take much more time and thought to fix so I tag them as needing overdraw prevention from the pipeline and they no longer exhibit the problem, but take a 50% hit in rendering~.

~I will submit an issue to try to recover their performance in a follow-on fix by doing a better job of creating their vertices.~

Update: I got inspired and implemented overdraw-less round-join rectangle vertices with no loss of performance.

When rapidly dragging items in a ReorderableList before animations complete, items would jump to their expected positions rather than smoothly transitioning. ## Problem

The issue occurs when a reorder animation is interrupted by starting a new drag operation. The interrupted animation would reset to the starting position of the original animation rather than capturing the current animated position, causing a visual jump. ## Solution This PR fixes the issue by: 1. Storing the previous target offset before updating to a new target 2. When an animation is interrupted, calculating the actual current position based on the animation's progress 3. Using this calculated position as the new starting point for the next animation

This PR is part of a series of `ReorderableList` enhancements I've developed for [TimeFinder](https://timefinder.app): - #172740 - #172380 - #172739 - #172738 Fixes #173243 ## Code Changes ```dart // Before _startOffset = offset; // After final double currentAnimValue = Curves.easeInOut.transform(_offsetAnimation\!.value); final Offset currentPosition = Offset.lerp(_startOffset, previousTarget, currentAnimValue)\!; _startOffset = currentPosition; ``` This ensures smooth transitions without visual jumping, making rapid reordering gestures feel more responsive and natural. ## Pre-launch Checklist - [x] I read the [Contributor Guide] and followed the process outlined there for submitting PRs. - [x] I read the [Tree Hygiene] page, which explains my responsibilities. - [x] I read and followed the [Flutter Style Guide], including [Features we expect every widget to implement]. - [x] I listed at least one issue that this PR fixes in the description above. - [x] I added new tests to check the change I am making, or this PR is [test-exempt]. - [x] I followed the [breaking change policy] and added [migration guide] as needed. - [x] All existing and new tests are passing. - [x] The analyzer (`flutter analyze --flutter-repo`) does not report any problems on my PR. - [x] I am willing to follow-up on review comments in a timely manner. [Contributor Guide]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Tree-hygiene.md#overview [Tree Hygiene]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Tree-hygiene.md [Flutter Style Guide]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo.md [Features we expect every widget to implement]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo.md#features-we-expect-every-widget-to-implement [test-exempt]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Tree-hygiene.md#tests [breaking change policy]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Tree-hygiene.md#handling-breaking-changes [migration guide]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/docs/contributing/Tree-hygiene.md#create-a-migration-guide

Would I need something more like build hooks to achieve my goal?
Will build hooks have access to current dart-define values?

When uploading app to playstore I understand that we need our app to have a unique version code for each build and in flutter the version code is said to be what follows + in pubspec.yaml.
e.g ```version: 1.0.0+3``` has a version code of 3 but when I upload my split apk's built using
```flutter build apk --split-per-abi```  to google play console has version code as 4003,2003&1003
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31410839/73180519-7761de80-413b-11ea-8faa-63837af1e1c0.png)

The problem is the version codes get huge when using split apks and it doesn't seem to respect the version number specified in `pubspec.yaml`.

edit: The question right now is if a user wishes to deploy split apks to the playstore, How should the app versioning be handled? Since the version numbers of split apk are huge when uploaded to playstore.

I understand if I set a versionCode=3

the split apk generated will be

ARM 32-bit): 1003
ARM 64-bit: 2003
x86 64-bit: 4003

but next time I set versionCode=4, play console won't accept build variants with version code less than 4003

the split apk generated will be

ARM 32-bit): 1004
ARM 64-bit: 2004
x86 64-bit: 4004

### Description

This PR enhances the CupertinoDatePicker by introducing a weekType parameter, giving developers more control over which days users can select.

### Solution

To address this, I've added a new weekType parameter to the CupertinoDatePicker widget. This parameter offers a declarative way to control the set of selectable days displayed in the picker, with options defined in a new WeekType enum:

WeekType.workDays (Monday-Friday)

WeekType.weekends (Saturday-Sunday)

WeekType.fullWeek (all days, current default behavior)

WeekType.custom (allows developers to provide a List<int> representing the DateTime.weekday values that should be visible and selectable).

### Example
```dart
// Example: Display only work days (Monday-Friday)
CupertinoDatePicker(
  mode: CupertinoDatePickerMode.date,
  initialDateTime: DateTime.now(),
  minimumDate: DateTime(2023, 1, 1),
  maximumDate: DateTime(2024, 12, 31),
  weekType: WeekType.workDays,
  onDateTimeChanged: (DateTime newDateTime) {
    // Handle date change
  },
);
```

Flutter has a ton of logic for handling keyboard shortcuts in the framework, mapping them in [default_text_editing_shortcuts.dart](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/default_text_editing_shortcuts.dart) and actually handling them privately [in editable_text.dart](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/4b82d47b012380ed952ab29e66033f62a3bcda84/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/editable_text.dart#L3105).  We should make this logic reusable by developers writing their own text editors.

## Why?

Previously, this logic was exposed in a class called `TextEditingActionTarget`, but that was removed in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/90684.  It was brought up in the [comments](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/90684#issuecomment-1029312785) after merge that this change had broken two major text editing projects.

Besides being impractical for developers to reimplement all of this logic on their own, doing so would quickly get out of sync with Flutter's behavior and cause strange discrepancies in text editing behavior between simple TextFields and the custom text editors.

## How?

The shortcuts and their behavior is already overridable by using Shortcuts and Actions widgets, but the problem is applying them to something other than an EditableText.  This was possible by mixing in `TextEditingActionTarget`, but it was brought up in the comments that [a composable solution may be preferred](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/90684#issuecomment-1029697048) instead.

We should flesh out this idea and then expose it publicly.

### Steps to reproduce

After upgrading to in_app_purchase_storekit 0.4.0 which use StoreKit2 there is a PlatformException when closing native ios product page/canceling on non consumable product
1. Press button to buy the non consumable product
2. close the native ios product page

### Expected results

there should be no PlatformException

### Actual results

there is PlatformException

## Description Hey! 👋 I'm trying to get the macOS VoiceOver working for Flutter websites and Flutter macOS apps. However, it's not working. It's working for all other macOS apps or all other websites except that one created with Flutter. https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24459435/201398484-4aa5fc1b-02a8-4e08-86b5-482a783b035b.mp4 I tested the https://gallery.flutter.dev for web and pulled the https://github.com/flutter/gallery (11.11.2022) repository to build & test the macOS (with `v3.5.0-10.0.pre.121`). ### Steps to reproduce 1. Go to https://gallery.flutter.dev 2. Enable VoiceOver in your macOS settings 3. Navigate with the tab key ### What I would expect I would expect that VoiceOver is working like it shown in this video by Flutter: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A6Sx0lBP8PI ### Specs macOS: 12.6 MacBook Pro M1

Currently the view focus enums in the embedder header are not namespaced, this can cause breakages if any application using the embedder API (or any library used by an application that uses the embedder API) defines similar enums. That's especially the case since the enum names are pretty generic, e.g. `kForward`, `kUndefined`. And this is not just hypothetical, this will actually cause a build breakage in flutter-pi once I roll the embedder header, since I am currently using `kForward` as a playback direction for the video player.

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/36e1db8f379a7d2c1cbf581b375f7b54b53b661c/engine/src/flutter/shell/platform/embedder/embedder.h#L1164-L1189

towards #141899

This is my attempt to handle https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/6537 for the VerticalDivider widget.

Updating AccessibilityBridge.java and AccessibilityBridgeTest.java to include `AccessibilityNodeInfo.CollectionItemInfo` to get TalkBack to announce item indexes for ListViews. 

- Updated the logic for adding CollectionInfo to add when the scrollChildren count is greater than 1. This is an attempt to exclude something like a SingleChildScrollView from getting CollectionInfo added. The only semantics info we can rely on from Android is the hasImplicitScrolling and the number of scrollChildren. 
- Added logic for adding the CollectionItemInfo to ListView children. It first checks to see if the parent node qualifies for CollectionInfo and then adds the CollectionItemInfo to the child view. The index values come from the `childrenInTraversalOrder`. We aren't currently passing the indexedSemantics into the SemanticsNode. Once those values are available, this can be made more robust. 

The following video includes the new changes with a ListView

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b9bf1b80-9f29-40e2-8f33-a08919554b7e


This video includes the logic with a SingleChildScrollView (no list announcements as expected)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8fe4dd24-cc5a-4a6b-b4b0-0f371fea20df

Fixes #168651 - This is a minimal fix. A full fix would be to pass the indexedSemantics to the SemanticsNode in Android and build the list with those values.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new Flutter app: flutter create blur_repaint_issue.
2. Replace lib/main.dart with the code sample below.
3. Run on a real iOS device (e.g., iOS 17.x) in profile mode: flutter run --profile.
4. Open DevTools > CPU profiler and Timeline; also enable Performance Overlay or Repaint Rainbow. In Xcode, open the Debug Navigator (View > Navigators > Show Debug Navigator or Cmd-7) to see live CPU, and for deeper profiling run Product > Profile (Cmd-I) to open Instruments and select “Time Profiler” and/or “Activity Monitor,” then attach to your app.
5. Leave the app idle on the home screen. Observe continuous frame rendering and CPU usage ~60–90%.
6. Toggle the booleans in the sample and reload:
7. Set useBackdropFilter = false → CPU drops and frames stop.
8 Set wrapInRepaintBoundary = false → still high CPU when useBackdropFilter = true.
9. Reduce blurSigma to 0 → CPU drops.

### Code sample

<details open><summary>Code sample</summary>

```
import 'dart:ui';
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(const MyApp());
}

class MyApp extends StatelessWidget {
  const MyApp({super.key});
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return const MaterialApp(
      debugShowCheckedModeBanner: false,
      home: Home(),
      // Alternatively: showPerformanceOverlay: true,
    );
  }
}

class Home extends StatelessWidget {
  const Home({super.key});

  // Toggle these to demonstrate the problem
  static const bool useBackdropFilter = true;
  static const bool wrapInRepaintBoundary = true;
  static const double blurSigma = 16; // setting to 0 removes the issue

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    final glass = GlassBox(
      blurSigma: blurSigma,
      useBackdropFilter: useBackdropFilter,
      wrapInRepaintBoundary: wrapInRepaintBoundary,
      child: const Text('Commentary', style: TextStyle(fontSize: 18)),
    );

    return Scaffold(
      body: Stack(
        fit: StackFit.expand,
        children: [
          Container(
            decoration: const BoxDecoration(
              gradient: LinearGradient(
                colors: [Color(0xFF0F2027), Color(0xFF203A43), Color(0xFF2C5364)],
                begin: Alignment.topLeft,
                end: Alignment.bottomRight,
              ),
            ),
          ),
          Center(
            child: SizedBox(
              width: 320,
              child: glass,
            ),
          ),
        ],
      ),
    );
  }
}

class GlassBox extends StatelessWidget {
  final Widget child;
  final double blurSigma;
  final bool useBackdropFilter;
  final bool wrapInRepaintBoundary;

  const GlassBox({
    super.key,
    required this.child,
    this.blurSigma = 16,
    this.useBackdropFilter = true,
    this.wrapInRepaintBoundary = true,
  });

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    Widget content = Container(
      decoration: BoxDecoration(
        color: Colors.white.withOpacity(0.08),
        borderRadius: BorderRadius.circular(16),
      ),
      padding: const EdgeInsets.symmetric(vertical: 14, horizontal: 18),
      child: child,
    );

    if (useBackdropFilter) {
      content = ClipRRect(
        borderRadius: BorderRadius.circular(16),
        child: BackdropFilter(
          filter: ImageFilter.blur(sigmaX: blurSigma, sigmaY: blurSigma),
          child: content,
        ),
      );
    }

    if (wrapInRepaintBoundary) {
      content = RepaintBoundary(child: content);
    }

    return content;
  }
}
```

</details>

### This PR fixes #166398
- Adds focus support for `CupertinoActionSheetAction`. This makes it work with keyboard shortcuts
- Creates new widget, `CupertinoTraversalGroup` that applies a Cupertino style focus border around its child when any of its descendant has focus
- Employs `CupertinoTraversalGroup` in `CupertinoActionSheet`

This PR introduces a `.separated` constructor to the `ReorderableListView` widget. The `.separated` constructor allows developers to define custom separators between the list items without the need to manually modify their list or create custom widgets. This API enhancement improves the overall usability and flexibility of `ReorderableListView`.

### Key Changes:

- Added a new `.separated` constructor to `ReorderableListView`.
- Included appropriate documentation for the new constructor with usage examples.
- Updated the relevant tests to verify the behavior of `.separated` functionality.
- Ensured backward compatibility for existing constructors.

This new feature addresses the requests in issue [#76706](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/76706).

Split from https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/41725 as the initial implementation as landed/published does not support this feature.

`NSView` doesn't have the same color and opacity controls that UIView does, so setting the background color will need alternate implementation (likely involving making the webview layer-backed).

The `mustache_template` code was forked from a project that rarely used explicit typing, even for things like function parameters, so there was a lot of implicit `dynamic` typing. To meet the analyzer requirements of flutter/packages, I added some explicit types, but in many cases it was just replacing an implicit dynamic with `Object?` to minimize the chance of regressions during import.

Over time, to improve the maintainability of the code, it would be good to audit the uses of `dynamic` and `Object?` in the package to see where we can add more specific types. This will need to be done carefully though, as it will create the potentially for regressions due to casting failures if there are edge cases where the actual runtime types are more broad than realized.

This change allows for the widget previewer to react to `activeLocationChanged` events sent over the `Editor` DTD service to automatically filter the set of visible previews based on the currently selected file in the IDE. This functionality can be turned on or off depending on whether or not the developer wants to see all previews in the project at once.

This change also includes some minor refactoring and UI changes to move the widget preview environment controls to a reserved area at the bottom of the preview window.

Please update 1 Device Type Per Pool to Android SDK 36 (Android 16). We have two kinds of devices that can be upgraded: Pixel 7 Pro and Samsung Galaxy 7 Pro.

- [ ] Upgrade 1 Samsung Galaxy Pro 7: https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/bot?id=flutter-devicelab-linux-74

- [ ] Upgrade 1 Samsung Galaxy Pro 7: https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/bot?id=flutter-devicelab-linux-77

##  **Prod Pool**
- [x] Upgrade 1 Pixel 7 Pro: https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/bot?id=flutter-devicelab-linux-1
- [ ] Upgrade 1 Samsung Galaxy Pro 7: https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/bot?id=flutter-devicelab-linux-80

## **Instructions to Upgrade Each Device**

This update can be done on the device, and it needs to be connected to wifi:
1. Before starting the upgrade, quarantine the bot. 
2. Navigate to Settings > System > Software Update
3. Select Install update
4. Wait 20-30 Minutes while update is installed.
5. Once complete, a restart button will appear. Press this and re-rack the phone.
6. Unqurantine the device.

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() => runApp(const MyApp());
